pros: Valuable service to uninsured patients.  I had some really good co-workers
cons:
The management was punitive and unethical.  CEO hired her friends from prior city whether qualified or not (some were qualified some obviously not). 

CEO extremely unprofessional, threatened to fire people in all staff meetings, talked down to staff, used intimidation.  Management does not value employee input, also two-faced. Would make policies and discipline employees for enforcing policies the moment a patient complained.  Would not listen to employee side of things.

Would not let providers use their vacation days. Unreasonable expectations for staff productivity.

Management can really ruin a good work environment.

So many good staff leave when they are not treated well or valued. While I worked there many loyal MDs left.

The board at Fetter must be clueless or incompetent.  I don't think they checked the CEO background before hiring.

pros: Able to work with poorer patients who really need access to care. Get paid a salary and don't have to worry about patients with no money.  The only viable way to work with the uninsured and underinsured.
cons: Management culture that is oriented to providing employment for African Americans, not necessarily the best qualified people they can find. Management, Board of Directors and staff are 90+% black. Obvious cultural bias towards this, and because of this there are people who are under-qualified in all areas. Pay and benefits are OK, but lots of hassles with management who don't value physician input.  They have new management since I left, but I doubt any significant change, as their operational priorities have always been this way.

pros: helping the community for their medical needs
cons: Turnover of staff, lack of communication from management to staff
